news.reference_string: With the debates at the European Council meetings of 10-11 December 2020, 24-25 June 2021 and 21-22 October 2021, the issue of EU values has finally arrived at the level of EU Heads of State or Government. Recent developments, including court rulings at both EU and Member State levels alluding to the rule of law, indicate that deep divisions persist in the EU regarding the understanding of democracy and European values; observers argue that the EU's rule of law crisis is still far from being resolved. EU leaders' various discussions have not led to a solution on the issue, but rather postponed direct action at European level for the moment. Consequently, EU leaders might need to return to this topic again in the near future. At their meeting of 24-25 March 2022, the President of the European Parliament, Roberta Metsola, urged EU leaders to use the current 'window of opportunity' to find a way forward on the rule of law. https://data.consilium.europa.eu/doc/document/ST-22-2020-INIT/en/pdfhttps://www.europarl.europa.eu/RegData/etudes/BRIE/2021/694201/EPRS_BRI(2021)694201_EN.pdfhttps://www.europarl.europa.eu/RegData/etudes/BRIE/2021/694243/EPRS_BRI(2021)694243_EN.pdfhttps://curia.europa.eu/jcms/upload/docs/application/pdf/2021-10/cp210192en.pdf https://curia.europa.eu/juris/document/document.jsf?text=&docid=244185&pageIndex=0&doclang=FR&mode=req&dir=&occ=first&part=1&cid=1699703 https://www.politico.eu/article/poland-legal-eu-court-reprimand-disciplinary-procedure-for-judges/ https://www.politico.eu/article/five-ways-the-eus-democracy-crisis-could-end/ https://eu.boell.org/en/2020/12/18/after-crisis-crisis-rule-law-headache-wont-go-away https://www.europarl.europa.eu/news/en/press-room/20220324IPR26159/this-is-our-moment-president-metsola-to-eu-leaders

Industrial policy has returned to the forefront of political agendas in the wake of the coronavirus crisis and the war in Ukraine. EU companies and politicians have realised that the supply chain disruptions, which the EU and the world have experienced, may severely disrupt the economy; proposed solutions notably point to the need of reinforcing manufacturing capacities in the EU and enhancing the EU's strategic autonomy. https://www.politico.eu/article/opinion-charles-michel-ukraine-war-going-big-for-european-union-industry/ https://www.europarl.europa.eu/thinktank/en/document/EPRS_BRI(2022)733589

In October 2022, in the context of the energy- and economy-related challenges facing the EU, the European Council called for all relevant EU and national level tools to be utilised to boost the resilience of the EU economy. However, they also noted the importance of preserving the level playing field and the 'integrity of the single market' whilst maintaining Europe's global competitiveness. The growing use of subsidies worldwide, more particularly the adoption of the US IRA, has caused concern for some in the EU, as it is considered as a discriminatory instrument, violating WTO rules and with potentially damaging effect on the EU's green tech industry. Despite differing views on how or whether to change State aid policy, the European Council agreed that it was imperative for the EU to be competitive and productive, particularly in sectors connected to the digital and green transitions. In February and March 2023, the European Council agreed that State aid policy needed adjusting in order to become simpler, faster and more predictable, allowing for temporary and proportionate support. Finding the correct balance between enabling State aid to support EU industry and preserving the level playing field in the single market will be a critical issue for the EU and its Member States to resolve over the coming months. To monitor these developments, the European Council has asked the Commission to report regularly on the impact of State aid policy on the single market as well as on the EU's competitiveness globally. https://www.europarl.europa.eu/thinktank/en/document/EPRS_BRI(2022)743681 https://www.oecd.org/subsidies/ https://www.whitehouse.gov/cleanenergy/inflation-reduction-act-guidebook/ https://borderlex.net/2023/02/21/think-tank-responding-to-the-united-states-green-tech-subsidies/ https://www.europarl.europa.eu/thinktank/en/document/EPRS_BRI(2023)739300 https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2023-01-18/why-eu-objects-to-us-green-subsidies-tax-breaks-quicktake?cmpid=BBD012723_BRUS&utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&utm_term=230127&utm_campaign=brussels&leadSource=uverify%20wall https://epthinktank.eu/2023/02/07/outlook-for-the-special-european-council-meeting-of-9-10-february-2023/#:%7E:text=and%20Annastiina%20Papunen.-,EU%20Heads%20of%20State%20or%20Government%20will%20gather%20on%209,migration%20and%20the%20EU%27s%20economy. https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/meetings/european-council/2023/02/09/

Taxation has been a very visible topic in the EU in recent years. According to some estimates, tax evasion, tax avoidance and aggressive tax planning could cause a loss of as much as €1 trillion in tax income to the EU annually. In its June 2018 conclusions, the European Council said that the 'fight against tax avoidance, evasion and fraud must be vigorously pursued both at global level (notably in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD)) and within the EU'. Commission President Ursula von der Leyen, in her political guidelines, outlined: 'I will ensure that taxation of big tech companies is a priority. I will work hard to ensure the proposals currently on the table are turned into law.' https://www.reuters.com/article/us-eu-tax-vanrompuy-idUSBRE93B0KC20130412https://data.consilium.europa.eu/doc/document/ST-9-2018-INIT/en/pdf https://op.europa.eu/en/publication-detail/-/publication/62e534f4-62c1-11ea-b735-01aa75ed71a1

title: European Council Conclusions: A Rolling Check-list of commitments to date
snippet: The role of the European Council – to 'provide the Union with the necessary impetus for its development' and to define its 'general political directions and priorities' – has evolved rapidly over the last decade. Since June 2014, the European Council Oversight Unit within the European Parliamentary Research Service (EPRS), the European Parliament's in-house research service and think tank, has been monitoring and analysing the European Council's delivery on commitments made in the conclusions of its meetings. This overview of European Council conclusions is an updated edition of the rolling check-list, which has been published regularly by the European Council Oversight Unit since 2014, covering conclusions adopted under the current institutional cycle. It is designed to review the degree of progress in achieving the goals that the European Council has set itself and to assist the Parliament in exercising its important oversight role in this field.

news.reference_string: As this global agreement needed to be turned into an EU law – requiring the unanimous agreement of all 27 Member States, in December 2021, the Commission proposed a directive on ensuring a global minimum level of taxation for multinational groups in the Union, which closely follows the international agreement with adjustments to ensure compliance with EU law. However, at the Ecofin meeting in Luxembourg on 5 April 2022, Poland blocked the EU agreement on the OECD minimum corporate tax rate. Although it had not raised objections during the OECD negotiation process last year, the country seems to have discovered an interest in a file that requires unanimity to be adopted in Council at a time when the EU has re-launched action against Poland on its rule of law backsliding. In the European Parliament, on 28 April 2022, the Economic and Monetary Affairs Committee gave broad support to the Commission proposal implementing into law the international agreement on a global minimum corporate tax rate. https://www.politico.eu/article/oecd-global-tax-deal-reached-g20/ https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?uri=CELEX%3A52021PC0823&qid=1641150862839 https://newsroom.consilium.europa.eu/events/20220405-economic-and-financial-affairs-council-april-2022 https://taxadviserseurope.org/project/cfes-tax-top-5-11-april-2022%EF%BF%BC/ https://www.europarl.europa.eu/news/en/press-room/20220425IPR27811/global-corporate-tax-rate-meps-approve-commission-main-ideas-in-committee-vote

producing a proposal as rapidly as possible. The Commission published its proposal on 27 May 2020, and the European Council agreed on the package at its meeting of 17-21 July 2020. A compromise deal on the long-term budget package including the MFF and Recovery Fund was finally reached by the EU institutions' negotiators in December 2020, after a stand-off with Hungary and Poland, with the (passive) support of Slovenia, blocking the deal in Council because of their objection to the rule of law conditionality stemming from their current national circumstances. https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/ip_20_940https://www.consilium.europa.eu/media/45109/210720-euco-final-conclusions-en.pdf https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/ip_20_2397 https://www.politico.eu/article/eu-should-hold-firm-against-hungary-poland-in-budget-fight-romanian-pm/

The EU supports the abovementioned tax package, even though it has been working on its own digital tax to deal with the issue. In 2018, the European Commission put forward two proposals for fair and effective taxation of the digital economy: a short-term solution, to be delivered by an interim digital services tax on revenues from certain digital services, and a permanent reform of corporate tax rules, based on the concept of 'significant digital presence'. Progress at EU level was stalled in an effort to find a global solution with the OECD. At the July 2020 European Council meeting, EU leaders tasked the Commission with putting forward a proposal on a digital levy in the first semester of 2021, considering ongoing OECD negotiations. As agreed in the interinstitutional agreement of 16 December 2020, such a levy was due to be one of the EU budget's new 'own resources' that would contribute to paying off EU debts incurred to finance the recovery package as well as play an important role in the fair taxation of digital companies. In December 2021, the Commission proposed a directive on ensuring a global minimum level of taxation for multinational groups in the Union, which closely follows the international agreement with adjustments to ensure compliance with EU law. In April 2022 at the Economic and Financial Affairs Council meeting, Poland vetoed the latest compromise proposal by the French Presidency, thereby blocking the file. It has been reported that the file has been blocked as a means to pressure the European Commission into approving the Polish recovery plans. https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/QANDA_21_3564https://ec.europa.eu/taxation_customs/business/company-tax/fair-taxation-digital-economy_enhttps://www.consilium.europa.eu/media/45109/210720-euco-final-conclusions-en.pdf https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?uri=uriserv:OJ.LI.2020.433.01.0028.01.ENG https://ec.europa.eu/info/strategy/eu-budget/long-term-eu-budget/2021-2027/revenue/potential-new-sources-revenue_en https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?uri=CELEX%3A52021PC0823&qid=1641150862839 https://newsroom.consilium.europa.eu/events/20220405-economic-and-financial-affairs-council-april-2022/134695-1-press-conference-part-1-20220405 https://www.politico.eu/newsletter/brussels-playbook/black-death-rule-of-law-polands-blockade/ https://www.euractiv.com/section/economy-jobs/news/poland-blocks-eu-directive-to-implement-global-corporate-tax-deal/

The European Council held a debate on the regional situation in the western Balkans in March 2017. The debate was of two-fold importance: 1) it reaffirmed the European perspective of the western Balkans and 2) placed enlargement back on the political agenda of the EU. At the end of 2019, however, the enlargement process was in stalemate with several Member States in the European Council opposing the opening of accession negotiations with North Macedonia and Albania, while France was calling for a revision of the enlargement rules. https://www.europarl.europa.eu/RegData/etudes/BRIE/2019/642801/EPRS_BRI(2019)642801_EN.pdf https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-50100201

Taxation has been a very visible topic in the EU in recent years. The European Parliament has set up several special committees with limited mandates over the years on the topic, TAXE, TAX2, TAX3, the PANA committee of inquiry, and in the current legislature, a new subcommittee on tax matters (FISC). They have all looked into tax evasion, tax avoidance and aggressive tax planning, which according to some estimates could cause a loss to the EU of as much as €1 trillion in tax income annually. https://www.europarl.europa.eu/doceo/document/TA-8-2015-0408_EN.htmlhttps://www.europarl.europa.eu/doceo/document/TA-8-2016-0310_EN.htmlhttps://www.europarl.europa.eu/doceo/document/TA-8-2019-0240_EN.html https://www.europarl.europa.eu/thinktank/en/document.html?reference=EPRS_ATA%282017%29614619 https://www.europarl.europa.eu/committees/en/fisc/home/highlights https://www.reuters.com/article/us-eu-tax-vanrompuy-idUSBRE93B0KC20130412

Security of 5G networks. The European Council stated in March 2019 that it looks forward 'to the Commission's recommendation on a concerted approach to the security of 5G networks'. The recommendation was published a few days after the European Council meeting. Since then, the security of 5G networks, and especially the involvement of the Chinese technology giant Huawei in building the networks, has been a widely discussed topic, notably following the move by the US to block Huawei from its market and to encourage its allies to adopt a similar approach. On 29 January 2020, the Commission published the EU toolbox on 5G cybersecurity, in which it outlined a set of key actions to ensure the security of the networks, such as limiting dependency on a single supplier and assessing the risk profile of supplies. The multivendor approach has been interpreted by Huawei as meaning that it will be able to take part in building the European 5G networks. The Commission has called on the Member States to 'take concrete and measurable steps' to implement key toolbox measures. EU leaders discussed 5G at their meeting on 1-2 October 2020 and stressed that 'potential 5G suppliers need to be assessed on the basis of common objective criteria' and asked the Member States to send their national plans on the roll-out of 5G to the Commission to 'ensure the rapid deployment of 5G across the EU'. https://data.consilium.europa.eu/doc/document/ST-1-2019-INIT/en/pdf https://ec.europa.eu/newsroom/dae/document.cfm?doc_id=58154 https://www.bloomberg.com/opinion/articles/2019-11-23/huawei-s-5g-networks-are-a-paralyzing-dilemma-for-the-west https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/ip_20_123 https://agenceurope.eu/en/bulletin/article/12414/7 https://huawei.eu/press-release/huawei-media-statement-following-publication-european-commissions-5g-security-toolbox https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/qanda_20_127 https://www.consilium.europa.eu/media/45910/021020-euco-final-conclusions.pdf?utm_source=dsms-auto&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=European+Council+conclusions%2c+1-2+October+2020

In October 2020, EU leaders held a strategic debate to discuss preparations ahead of the next meeting with the African Union (AU) on 9 December 2020. This meeting was cancelled again, this time due to scheduling issues. In February 2022, the heads of state or government of the Member States of the EU and the AU met for the sixth EU-AU summit. Both sides agreed to boost regional and continental economic integration through trade. The issue of waiving intellectual property rights on vaccines caused tension between both parties in advance of the summit and it had been under discussion at the World Trade Organization since October 2020. However, in their joint statement the EU and the AU agreed to engage 'constructively towards an agreement on a comprehensive WTO response to the pandemic, which includes trade-related, as well as intellectual property related aspects'. Discussions appear to be making genuine progress and the European Council welcomed this at its meeting in March 2022. https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2020/10/16/european-council-conclusions-15-16-october-2020/ https://www.politico.eu/article/eu-au-videoconference-postponed-over-agenda-issues/ https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2022/02/18/sixth-european-union-african-union-summit-a-joint-vision-for-2030/#:%7E:text=14%3A20-,Sixth%20European%20Union%20%2D%20African%20Union%20Summit%3A%20A%20Joint%20Vision%20for,the%20European%20Council%20and%20H.E. https://ustr.gov/about-us/policy-offices/press-office/press-releases/2022/march/statement-ustr-spokesperson-adam-hodge-wto-trips-waiver-discussions https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/meetings/european-council/2022/03/24-25/

The discussions on financial solidarity and on how to fund the crisis and recovery package have not been fluid. Differing approaches, on notably the Recovery Fund, led the EU ministers to ask the European Council for guidance. However, considering these differences in views, EU leaders decided to move the issue to the Commission's table and tasked it with analysing the exact needs and https://www.consilium.europa.eu/media/43300/200410_peg-centeno-letter-to-pec-michel_covid.pdf https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-eu-dombrovskis/eu-could-finance-1-5-trillion-euro-recovery-fund-with-bonds-dombrovskis-idUSKCN21W0KG https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2020/04/09/report-on-the-comprehensive-economic-policy-response-to-the-covid-19-pandemic/ https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2020/04/23/conclusions-by-president-charles-michel-following-the-video-conference-with-members-of-the-european-council-on-23-april-2020/

The European Council has been active during the crisis, and, like many actors, has taken a digital leap with its video-meetings. This new form of meetings has enabled EU leaders in a context of lockdown to take joint action to tackle the crisis. Considering the particular nature of the European Council however, and notably the importance of small bilateral meetings on the side-lines in achieving agreements, video meetings are unlikely to replace physical meetings fully when crucial decisions are on the agenda. In such a format, EU leaders tend to be more cautious and keep to their written statements since the confidentiality of discussions is not ensured and participation is https://www.politico.eu/article/coronavirus-european-leaders-to-hold-videoconference/ https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2020/04/23/conclusions-by-president-charles-michel-following-the-video-conference-with-members-of-the-european-council-on-23-april-2020/ https://www.euractiv.com/section/global-europe/news/can-the-eu-be-run-by-videolink-confidentiality-is-the-biggest-problem/

The issue of rule of law developments in Poland was added to the agenda of the 21-22 October European Council at the last moment. EU leaders discussed the recent ruling of Poland's Constitutional Tribunal, which states that some parts of the EU Treaties are incompatible with the Polish Constitution, and also raised the issue of judicial independence in the country more broadly. https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/polish-constitutional-tribunal-some-articles-eu-treaties-unconstitutional-2021-10-07/https://twitter.com/diego_bxl/status/1451166150507782146https://www.europarl.europa.eu/RegData/etudes/BRIE/2021/696173/EPRS_BRI(2021)696173_EN.pdf

In the digital age, earning profit in a country no longer necessarily requires setting-up factories or offices on the ground, but can be effected by offering products or services through digital platforms. This results in the difficulty of localising value creation, and as a result, the ensuing taxation questions become increasingly complicated. The issue has caused some transatlantic tensions, as the United States (US) has a very strong 'big tech' digital presence around the world. The US has raised the possibility to impose unilateral tariffs if EU countries were to go ahead with a digital levy. In its March 2021 meeting, the European Council has expressed its preference for and commitment to a global solution within the OECD framework. However, it did not rule out a unilateral EU move if a global solution was not achieved. The European Parliament adopted its position on the matter in April 2021, emphasising that the global solution was the preferred one, but not the only way forward. Multilateral talks finally resulted in an agreement at OECD level in July 2021, the details of which were finalised on 8 October 2021. In the end, all EU Member States accepted to endorse the deal and to be included in the digital taxation framework, which was endorsed by the G20 leaders' meeting in Rome on 31 October. The agreement envisages a global minimum tax rate of at least 15 % and is designed to clarify tax revenue sharing among countries for multinational companies making profits in countries without a physical presence, especially by big digital companies. In July 2021, the European Commission announced that it would suspend work on its own digital levy until the autumn to prioritise the global agreement, although under the interinstitutional agreement of 16 December 2020 this initiative was supposed to be put forward by June 2021. The OECD/G20 agreement has been welcomed by Commission President Ursula von der Leyen, and Commissioner Gentiloni has hailed its formal endorsement by the G20. https://www.politico.eu/article/eu-to-postpone-digital-tax-proposal/https://www.consilium.europa.eu/media/48976/250321-vtc-euco-statement-en.pdfhttps://www.europarl.europa.eu/doceo/document/TA-9-2021-0147_EN.htmlhttps://www.oecd.org/newsroom/130-countries-and-jurisdictions-join-bold-new-framework-for-international-tax-reform.htmhttps://www.oecd.org/tax/oecd-leading-multilateral-efforts-to-address-tax-challenges-from-digitalisation-of-the-economy.htmhttps://www.ft.com/content/3e3e6a7d-67d5-437d-a7b2-29c52ce9c78fhttps://www.consilium.europa.eu/media/52732/final-final-g20-rome-declaration.pdf https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?uri=uriserv:OJ.LI.2020.433.01.0028.01.ENG https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/statement_21_5166 https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/STATEMENT_21_5247

Government. Recent developments, including court rulings at both EU and Member State levels alluding to the rule of law, indicate that deep divisions persist in the EU regarding the understanding of democracy and European values; observers argue that the EU's rule of law crisis is still far from being resolved. EU leaders' various discussions have not led to a solution on the issue, but rather postponed direct action at European level for the moment. Consequently, EU leaders might need to return to this topic again in the near future. At their meeting of 24-25 March 2022, the President of the European Parliament, Roberta Metsola, urged EU leaders to use the current 'window of opportunity' to find a way forward on the rule of law. https://curia.europa.eu/jcms/upload/docs/application/pdf/2021-10/cp210192en.pdf https://curia.europa.eu/juris/document/document.jsf?text=&docid=244185&pageIndex=0&doclang=FR&mode=req&dir=&occ=first&part=1&cid=1699703 https://www.politico.eu/article/poland-legal-eu-court-reprimand-disciplinary-procedure-for-judges/ https://www.politico.eu/article/five-ways-the-eus-democracy-crisis-could-end/ https://eu.boell.org/en/2020/12/18/after-crisis-crisis-rule-law-headache-wont-go-away https://www.europarl.europa.eu/news/en/press-room/20220324IPR26159/this-is-our-moment-president-metsola-to-eu-leaders

A further issue to contend with is the renewed discussions on the revision of fiscal coordination and the European Semester. The Stability and Growth Pact (SGP) was developed as part of the introduction of the euro and was reinforced in the aftermath of the sovereign debt crisis. The framework aims to keep countries' deficit below 3 % of economic output and their public debt below 60 %. Current rules allow Member States some leeway to bend the rules and get away without any fines, which could, if applied (not applied until now) amount to 0.2 % of the country's GDP. Eurozone debt decreased slightly to 95.6 % of economic output (88.1 % of GDP in EU as a whole) in the fourth quarter of 2021, compared with 100 % at the end of the first quarter, with the highest levels reached in Greece, Italy, Portugal, Spain, France, Belgium and Cyprus. The Commission has relaunched the debate on the review of EU economic governance, which had begun before the pandemic; the crisis led the EU to suspend the rules in March 2020 by activating the so-called general escape clause. This move enabled governments to take a supportive fiscal stance and to support their economies in the face of the economic and social impact of the pandemic. The rules are set to be applied again only in 2023 on the basis of the Commission's spring 2021 economic forecast. https://pro.politico.eu/news/138913 https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/documents/2995521/14497745/2-22042022-BP-EN.pdf/90896015-2ac1-081a-2eef-ad8d5f2c0da1 https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/SPEECH_21_5374 https://ec.europa.eu/info/business-economy-euro/economic-and-fiscal-policy-coordination/economic-governance-review_en https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/ip_21_2722

During the coronavirus crisis, the 'solidarity clause' in Article 122 TFEU has been used as legal basis for some of the actions taken to tackle the crisis and support the EU economy in the recovery process. Paragraph 2 states that 'where a Member State is in difficulties or is seriously threatened with severe difficulties caused by natural disasters or exceptional occurrences beyond its control, the Council, on a proposal from the Commission, may grant, under certain conditions, Union financial assistance to the Member State concerned'. The European Council is not specifically mentioned in this article. https://www.politico.eu/article/coronavirus-angela-merkel-eu-bonds/https://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:12008E122:EN:HTML

Another challenging factor during the coronavirus crisis has been the German federal constitutional court's critical ruling on the European Central Bank's bond buying programme, which has met with mixed reactions. https://www.ft.com/content/a1beda5e-5c2d-429e-a095-27728ed2d72b https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/statement_20_846 https://www.ft.com/content/f48e3a6b-6a95-4187-8a7d-0f8dad3fbecb

In recent weeks and months, the EU-China relationship has further deteriorated. When Taiwan opened a representative office in Lithuania, China reportedly responded by imposing an import ban, an export ban and restriction of services to and from Lithuania or linked to Lithuania. This led to the EU launching a case against China at the WTO for 'discriminatory trade practices' that impact both Lithuania and the EU single market. https://www.politico.eu/article/eu-sues-china-wto-lithuania-blockade/ https://docs.wto.org/dol2fe/Pages/SS/directdoc.aspx?filename=q:/WT/DS/610-1.pdf&Open=True https://trade.ec.europa.eu/doclib/press/index.cfm?id=2355

title: European Council Conclusions: A Rolling Check-list of commitments to date
snippet: The role of the European Council – to 'provide the Union with the necessary impetus for its development' and to define its 'general political directions and priorities' – has evolved rapidly over the last decade. Since June 2014, the European Council Oversight Unit within the European Parliamentary Research Service (EPRS), the European Parliament's in-house research service and think tank, has been monitoring and analysing the European Council's delivery on commitments made in the conclusions of its meetings. This overview of European Council conclusions is an updated edition of the rolling check-list, which has been published regularly by the European Council Oversight Unit since 2014, covering conclusions adopted under the current institutional cycle. It is designed to review the degree of progress in achieving the goals that the European Council has set itself and to assist the Parliament in exercising its important oversight role in this field.

news.reference_string: In the digital age, earning profit in a country no longer necessarily requires setting-up factories or offices on the ground, but can be effected by offering products or services through digital platforms. This results in the difficulty of localising value creation, and as a result, the ensuing taxation questions become increasingly complicated. The issue has caused some transatlantic tensions, as the United States (US) has a very strong 'big tech' digital presence around the world. The US has raised the possibility to impose unilateral tariffs if EU countries were to go ahead with a digital levy. In its March 2021 meeting, the European Council has expressed its preference for and commitment to a global solution within the OECD framework. However, it did not rule out a unilateral EU move if a global solution was not achieved. https://www.politico.eu/article/eu-to-postpone-digital-tax-proposal/https://www.consilium.europa.eu/media/48976/250321-vtc-euco-statement-en.pdf

Security of 5G networks. The European Council stated in March 2019 that it looks forward 'to the Commission's recommendation on a concerted approach to the security of 5G networks'. The recommendation was published a few days after the European Council meeting. Since then, the security of 5G networks, and especially the involvement of the Chinese technology giant Huawei in building the networks, has been a widely discussed topic, notably following the move by the US to block Huawei from its market and to encourage its allies to adopt a similar approach. On https://data.consilium.europa.eu/doc/document/ST-1-2019-INIT/en/pdf https://ec.europa.eu/newsroom/dae/document.cfm?doc_id=58154 https://www.bloomberg.com/opinion/articles/2019-11-23/huawei-s-5g-networks-are-a-paralyzing-dilemma-for-the-west

The coronavirus crisis has had an unprecedented impact on the euro area, with economic output shrinking by 6 % in 2020, and, the following year, a sharp rise in inflation: in the summer of 2022, the annual rate reached 9.1 % in the euro area, and 10.1 % in the EU. The shock to EU economies has been symmetrical, and recovery has been stopped short. The discussions on financial solidarity and on how to fund the crisis and recovery package have not been fluid. Differing approaches, on notably the Recovery Fund, led the EU ministers to ask the European Council for guidance. However, considering these differences in views, EU leaders decided to move the issue to the Commission's table and tasked it with analysing the exact needs and producing a proposal as rapidly as possible. The Commission published its proposal on 27 May 2020, and the European Council agreed on the package at its meeting of 17-21 July 2020. A compromise deal on the long-term budget package including the MFF and Recovery Fund was finally reached by the EU institutions' negotiators in December 2020, after a stand-off with Hungary and Poland, with the (passive) support of Slovenia, blocking the deal in the Council because of their objection to the rule of law conditionality stemming from their current national circumstances. https://ec.europa.eu/info/sites/default/files/economy-finance/ip156_en.pdfhttps://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/statistics-explained/index.php?title=Inflation_in_the_euro_area#Euro_area_annual_inflation_rate_and_its_main_componentshttps://www.consilium.europa.eu/media/43300/200410_peg-centeno-letter-to-pec-michel_covid.pdfhttps://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-eu-dombrovskis/eu-could-finance-1-5-trillion-euro-recovery-fund-with-bonds-dombrovskis-idUSKCN21W0KGhttps://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2020/04/09/report-on-the-comprehensive-economic-policy-response-to-the-covid-19-pandemic/https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2020/04/23/conclusions-by-president-charles-michel-following-the-video-conference-with-members-of-the-european-council-on-23-april-2020/https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/ip_20_940https://www.consilium.europa.eu/media/45109/210720-euco-final-conclusions-en.pdf https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/ip_20_2397 https://www.politico.eu/article/eu-should-hold-firm-against-hungary-poland-in-budget-fight-romanian-pm/

With the debates at the European Council meetings of 10-11 December 2020, 24-25 June 2021 and 21-22 October 2021, the issue of EU values has finally arrived at the level of EU Heads of State or Government. Recent developments, including court rulings at both EU and Member State levels alluding to the rule of law, indicate that deep divisions persist in the EU regarding the understanding of democracy and European values; observers argue that the EU's rule of law crisis is still far from being resolved. EU leaders' various discussions have not led to a solution on the issue, but rather postponed direct action at European level for the moment. Consequently, EU leaders might need to return to this topic again in the near future. At their meeting of 24-25 March 2022, the President of the European Parliament, Roberta Metsola, urged EU leaders to use the current 'window of opportunity' to find a way forward on the rule of law. https://data.consilium.europa.eu/doc/document/ST-22-2020-INIT/en/pdfhttps://www.europarl.europa.eu/RegData/etudes/BRIE/2021/694201/EPRS_BRI(2021)694201_EN.pdfhttps://www.europarl.europa.eu/RegData/etudes/BRIE/2021/694243/EPRS_BRI(2021)694243_EN.pdfhttps://curia.europa.eu/jcms/upload/docs/application/pdf/2021-10/cp210192en.pdf https://curia.europa.eu/juris/document/document.jsf?text=&docid=244185&pageIndex=0&doclang=FR&mode=req&dir=&occ=first&part=1&cid=1699703 https://www.politico.eu/article/poland-legal-eu-court-reprimand-disciplinary-procedure-for-judges/ https://www.politico.eu/article/five-ways-the-eus-democracy-crisis-could-end/ https://eu.boell.org/en/2020/12/18/after-crisis-crisis-rule-law-headache-wont-go-away https://www.europarl.europa.eu/news/en/press-room/20220324IPR26159/this-is-our-moment-president-metsola-to-eu-leaders

As this global agreement needed to be turned into an EU law – requiring the unanimous agreement of all 27 Member States, in December 2021, the Commission proposed a directive on ensuring a global minimum level of taxation for multinational groups in the Union, which closely follows the international agreement with adjustments to ensure compliance with EU law. However, at the Ecofin meeting in Luxembourg on 5 April 2022, Poland blocked the EU agreement on the OECD minimum corporate tax rate. Although it had not raised objections during the OECD negotiation process last year, the country seems to have discovered an interest in a file that requires unanimity to be adopted in the Council at a time when the EU has re-launched action against Poland on its rule of law backsliding. In the European Parliament, on 28 April 2022, the Economic and Monetary Affairs Committee gave broad support to the Commission proposal implementing into law the international agreement on a global minimum corporate tax rate. https://www.politico.eu/article/oecd-global-tax-deal-reached-g20/ https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?uri=CELEX%3A52021PC0823&qid=1641150862839 https://newsroom.consilium.europa.eu/events/20220405-economic-and-financial-affairs-council-april-2022 https://taxadviserseurope.org/project/cfes-tax-top-5-11-april-2022%EF%BF%BC/ https://www.europarl.europa.eu/news/en/press-room/20220425IPR27811/global-corporate-tax-rate-meps-approve-commission-main-ideas-in-committee-vote

Taxation has been a very visible topic in the EU in recent years. The European Parliament has set up several special committees with limited mandates over the years on the topic, TAXE, TAX2, TAX3, the PANA committee of inquiry, and in the current legislature, a new subcommittee on tax matters (FISC). They have all looked into tax evasion, tax avoidance and aggressive tax planning, which according to some estimates could cause a loss to the EU of as much as €1 trillion in tax income annually. https://www.europarl.europa.eu/doceo/document/TA-8-2015-0408_EN.htmlhttps://www.europarl.europa.eu/doceo/document/TA-8-2016-0310_EN.htmlhttps://www.europarl.europa.eu/doceo/document/TA-8-2019-0240_EN.html https://www.europarl.europa.eu/thinktank/en/document/EPRS_ATA(2017)614619 https://www.europarl.europa.eu/committees/en/fisc/home/highlights https://www.reuters.com/article/us-eu-tax-vanrompuy-idUSBRE93B0KC20130412

The EU supports the above-mentioned tax package, even though it has been working on its own digital tax to deal with the issue. In 2018, the European Commission put forward two proposals for fair and effective taxation of the digital economy: a short-term solution, to be delivered by an interim digital services tax on revenues from certain digital services, and a permanent reform of corporate tax rules, based on the concept of 'significant digital presence'. Progress at EU level was stalled in an effort to find a global solution with the OECD. At the July 2020 European Council meeting, EU leaders tasked the Commission with putting forward a proposal on a digital levy in the first semester of 2021, considering ongoing OECD negotiations. As agreed in the interinstitutional agreement of 16 December 2020, such a levy was due to be one of the EU budget's new 'own resources' that would contribute to paying off EU debts incurred to finance the recovery package as well as play an important role in the fair taxation of digital companies. In December 2021, the Commission proposed a directive on ensuring a global minimum level of taxation for multinational groups in the Union, which closely follows the international agreement with adjustments to ensure compliance with EU law. In April 2022 at the Economic and Financial Affairs Council meeting, Poland vetoed the latest compromise proposal by the French Presidency, thereby blocking the file. It has been reported that the file has been blocked as a means to pressure the European Commission into approving the Polish recovery plans. https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/QANDA_21_3564https://ec.europa.eu/taxation_customs/business/company-tax/fair-taxation-digital-economy_enhttps://www.consilium.europa.eu/media/45109/210720-euco-final-conclusions-en.pdf https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?uri=uriserv:OJ.LI.2020.433.01.0028.01.ENG https://ec.europa.eu/info/strategy/eu-budget/long-term-eu-budget/2021-2027/revenue/potential-new-sources-revenue_en https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?uri=CELEX%3A52021PC0823&qid=1641150862839 https://newsroom.consilium.europa.eu/events/20220405-economic-and-financial-affairs-council-april-2022/134695-1-press-conference-part-1-20220405 https://www.politico.eu/newsletter/brussels-playbook/black-death-rule-of-law-polands-blockade/ https://www.euractiv.com/section/economy-jobs/news/poland-blocks-eu-directive-to-implement-global-corporate-tax-deal/

Another challenging factor during the coronavirus crisis has been the German federal constitutional court's critical ruling on the European Central Bank's bond buying programme, which has met with mixed reactions. https://www.ft.com/content/a1beda5e-5c2d-429e-a095-27728ed2d72b https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/statement_20_846 https://www.ft.com/content/f48e3a6b-6a95-4187-8a7d-0f8dad3fbecb

The issue of rule of law developments in Poland was added to the agenda of the 21-22 October European Council at the last moment. EU leaders discussed the recent ruling of Poland's Constitutional Tribunal, which states that some parts of the EU Treaties are incompatible with the Polish Constitution, and also raised the issue of judicial independence in the country more broadly. https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/polish-constitutional-tribunal-some-articles-eu-treaties-unconstitutional-2021-10-07/https://twitter.com/diego_bxl/status/1451166150507782146https://www.europarl.europa.eu/RegData/etudes/BRIE/2021/696173/EPRS_BRI(2021)696173_EN.pdf

In March 2020 the Commission and HR/VP unveiled a communication 'Towards a comprehensive strategy with Africa', scheduled for adoption at the October 2020 European Union-African Union summit, which had however to be postponed due to COVID-19. In October 2020, EU leaders held a strategic debate to discuss preparations ahead of the next meeting with the African Union (AU) on 9 December 2020. This meeting was cancelled again, this time due to scheduling issues. https://agenceurope.eu/en/bulletin/article/12439/12 https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2020/10/16/european-council-conclusions-15-16-october-2020/ https://www.politico.eu/article/eu-au-videoconference-postponed-over-agenda-issues/

Following the Charlie Hebdo attacks, for example, after which millions of people had expressed their solidarity with the victims (through the 'Je suis Charlie' movement), an informal European Council meeting was held on 12 February 2015. At that meeting, Heads of State or Government adopted a statement on anti-terrorism measures, vowing to take stronger measures against terrorist threats in the coming months. As mentioned previously, the meeting of 17-18 December 2015, following the terrorist attacks in Paris in November 2015, constitutes a clear example of a major agenda change, with the European Council dedicating significant time to internal security and/or terrorism, although the issues had not originally been foreseen on the agenda. https://www.reuters.com/article/us-france-shooting/french-foreign-leaders-walk-arm-in-arm-as-millions-protest-paris-attacks-idUSKBN0KK05S20150111?utm_source=Facebook https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2015/02/12/european-council-statement-fight-against-terrorism/

title: Tracking the EU Commissioners’ commitments - Von der Leyen Commission, 2019 - 2024
snippet: This document is a compilation of briefings that track the commitments made by the Vice-Presidents and Commissioners to the European Parliament – in their written answers to Parliament’s questions, at their hearings, and, in some cases, in subsequent appearances before Parliament’s committees. The document provides an overview of the state-of-play at the mid-term of the von der Leyen Commission. Since many of these commitments were made, major international crises have shifted some political priorities. The Vice-Presidents’ and Commissioners’ progress on their commitments should be considered in this context.

title: Demographic Outlook for the European Union 2022
snippet: The latest demographic data show that existing demographic tendencies, such as increasing median age, declining fertility rates and a shrinking working age population, continue to prevail. However, it is also becoming clear that the influence of the pandemic in 2021 was more significant than during the previous year – for instance, 'excess mortality' increased even further, while life expectancy decreased in many Member States. The pandemic also accelerated another phenomenon, present in our lives in recent decades: the digital transition. Social distancing measures favoured automation and digitisation, an increased use of e-government, and led to higher rates of remote working. Parallel to this, new problems and challenges appeared, touching diverse demographic groups in different ways and to differing degrees. Digital fraud, cyber-threats, digital dependency and a deepening digital divide pose more and more challenges for citizens and the EU.

title: The Role of AI in the European Green Deal
snippet: AI can be deployed for a wide range of applications to promote the goals of the European Green Deal. However, adverse environmental impacts of AI could jeopardise the attainment of these goals. The report describes environmental potentials, clarifies characteristics and causes of environmental risks, and outlines initiatives and best practices for environmental policies. It illustrates the need for regulatory action to align design and deployment of AI with the goals of the European Green Deal and concludes with specific recommendations.

title: Research for REGI Committee - Artificial Intelligence and Urban Development
snippet: This research paper explores the role of artificial intelligence (AI) in urban areas, and its impact on socio-economic and territorial cohesion. It argues that expectations surrounding AI are high, especially in the context of smart-city initiatives, but that the actual benefits are yet to be fully assessed. To avoid potential risks, local and urban authorities need to fulfil a series of conditions that are inherently challenging. The EU’s AI Policy and its Cohesion Policy, in particular, may help, but they need to address the territorial dimension of AI more explicitly.

title: European Council Conclusions: A Rolling Check-list of commitments to date
snippet: Since June 2014, the European Council Oversight Unit within the European Parliamentary Research Service (EPRS), the European Parliament's in-house research service and think-tank, has been monitoring and analysing the European Council's delivery on commitments made in the conclusions of its meetings. This overview of European Council conclusions is the latest edition of the Rolling Check-List, which has been published regularly by the European Council Oversight Unit since 2014. It is designed to review the degree of progress in achieving the goals that the European Council has set itself and to assist the Parliament in exercising its important oversight role in this field.

news.reference_string: Security of 5G networks. The European Council stated in March 2019 that it looks forward 'to the Commission's recommendation on a concerted approach to the security of 5G networks'. The recommendation was published a few days after the European Council meeting. Since then, the security of 5G networks, and especially the involvement of the Chinese technology giant Huawei in building the networks, has been a widely discussed topic, notably following the move by the US to block Huawei from its market and to encourage its allies to adopt a similar approach. On 29 January 2020, the Commission published the EU toolbox on 5G cybersecurity, in which it outlined a set of key actions to ensure the security of the networks, such as limiting dependency on a single supplier and assessing the risk profile of supplies. The multivendor approach has been interpreted by Huawei as meaning that it will be able to take part in building the European 5G networks. The Commission has called on the Member States to 'take concrete and measurable steps' to implement key toolbox measures. EU leaders discussed 5G at their meeting on 1-2 October 2020 and stressed that 'potential 5G suppliers need to be assessed on the basis of common objective criteria' and asked the Member States to send their national plans on the roll-out of 5G to the Commission to 'ensure the rapid deployment of 5G across the EU'. https://data.consilium.europa.eu/doc/document/ST-1-2019-INIT/en/pdf https://ec.europa.eu/newsroom/dae/document.cfm?doc_id=58154 https://www.bloomberg.com/opinion/articles/2019-11-23/huawei-s-5g-networks-are-a-paralyzing-dilemma-for-the-west https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/ip_20_123 https://agenceurope.eu/en/bulletin/article/12414/7 https://huawei.eu/press-release/huawei-media-statement-following-publication-european-commissions-5g-security-toolbox https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/qanda_20_127 https://www.consilium.europa.eu/media/45910/021020-euco-final-conclusions.pdf?utm_source=dsms-auto&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=European+Council+conclusions%2c+1-2+October+2020

Taxation has been a very visible topic in the EU in recent years. The European Parliament has set up several special committees with limited mandates over the years on the topic, TAXE, TAX2, TAX3, the PANA committee of inquiry, and in the current legislature, a new subcommittee on tax matters (FISC). They have all looked into tax evasion, tax avoidance and aggressive tax planning, which according to some estimates could cause a loss to the EU of as much as €1 trillion in tax income annually. https://www.europarl.europa.eu/doceo/document/TA-8-2015-0408_EN.htmlhttps://www.europarl.europa.eu/doceo/document/TA-8-2016-0310_EN.htmlhttps://www.europarl.europa.eu/doceo/document/TA-8-2019-0240_EN.html https://www.europarl.europa.eu/thinktank/en/document.html?reference=EPRS_ATA%282017%29614619 https://www.europarl.europa.eu/committees/en/fisc/home/highlights https://www.reuters.com/article/us-eu-tax-vanrompuy-idUSBRE93B0KC20130412

Regarding market access, discussions resumed on an international procurement instrument (IPI). The aim is to increase the EU's leverage when negotiating access to procurement markets in third countries. The instrument would allow the Commission to open an investigation, and if any alleged discrimination against EU companies were to be proven, it would lead to consultations with the third country concerned, and ultimately, price penalties could be applied to the tenders originating there. Progress on this file had slowed down however in the context of the public health crisis. This resulted not only from the limited meeting possibilities, but also from existing political sensitivities regarding the file. However, at their meeting on 1-2 October 2020, EU Heads of State or Government called for progress to be hastened. https://www.europarl.europa.eu/legislative-train/theme-a-balanced-and-progressive-trade-policy-to-harness-globalisation/file-international-procurement-instrument-(ipi) https://www.europarl.europa.eu/thinktank/en/document.html?reference=EPRS_IDA(2019)644201 https://pro.politico.eu/news/117506 https://www.euractiv.com/section/economy-jobs/news/eus-procurement-reform-faces-uphill-struggle/ https://www.consilium.europa.eu/media/45910/021020-euco-final-conclusions.pdf?utm_source=dsms-auto&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=European+Council+conclusions%2c+1-2+October+2020

The European Council held a debate on the regional situation in the western Balkans in March 2017. The debate was of two-fold importance: 1) it reaffirmed the European perspective of the western Balkans and 2) placed enlargement back on the political agenda of the EU. At the end of 2019, however, the enlargement process was in stalemate with several Member States in the European Council opposing the opening of accession negotiations with North Macedonia and Albania, while France was calling for a revision of the enlargement rules. https://www.europarl.europa.eu/RegData/etudes/BRIE/2019/642801/EPRS_BRI(2019)642801_EN.pdf https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-50100201

Digital taxation. In the digital age, earning profit in a country no longer necessarily requires settingup factories or offices on the ground, but can be effected by offering products or services through digital platforms. This results in the difficulty of localising value creation, and as a result, the ensuing taxation questions become increasingly complicated. The issue has caused some transatlantic tensions, as the United States (US) has a very strong 'big tech' digital presence around the world. The US has raised the possibility to impose unilateral tariffs if EU countries were to go ahead with a digital levy. In its March 2021 meeting, the European Council has expressed its preference for and commitment to a global solution within the OECD framework. However, it did not rule out a unilateral EU move if a global solution was not achieved. The European Parliament adopted its position on the matter in April 2021, emphasising that the global solution was the preferred one, but not the only way forward. Multilateral talks finally resulted in an agreement at OECD level in July 2021, the details of which were finalised on 8 October 2021. In the end, all EU Member States accepted to endorse the deal and to be included in the digital taxation framework, which was endorsed by the G20 leaders' meeting in Rome on 31 October. The agreement envisages a global minimum tax rate of at least 15 % and is designed to clarify tax revenue sharing among countries for multinational companies making profits in countries without a physical presence, especially by big digital companies. In July 2021, the European Commission announced that it would suspend work on its own digital levy until the autumn to prioritise the global agreement, although under the interinstitutional agreement of 16 December 2020 this initiative was supposed to be put forward by June 2021. The OECD/G20 agreement has been welcomed by Commission President Ursula von der Leyen, and Commissioner Gentiloni has hailed its formal endorsement by the G20. Its implementation is envisaged in the 2022 Commission work programme. https://www.politico.eu/article/eu-to-postpone-digital-tax-proposal/https://www.consilium.europa.eu/media/48976/250321-vtc-euco-statement-en.pdfhttps://www.europarl.europa.eu/doceo/document/TA-9-2021-0147_EN.htmlhttps://www.oecd.org/newsroom/130-countries-and-jurisdictions-join-bold-new-framework-for-international-tax-reform.htmhttps://www.oecd.org/tax/oecd-leading-multilateral-efforts-to-address-tax-challenges-from-digitalisation-of-the-economy.htmhttps://www.ft.com/content/3e3e6a7d-67d5-437d-a7b2-29c52ce9c78fhttps://www.consilium.europa.eu/media/52732/final-final-g20-rome-declaration.pdfhttps://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?uri=uriserv:OJ.LI.2020.433.01.0028.01.ENGhttps://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/statement_21_5166https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/STATEMENT_21_5247https://eur-lex.europa.eu/resource.html?uri=cellar%3A9fb5131e-30e9-11ec-bd8e-01aa75ed71a1.0001.02/DOC_2&format=PDF

The discussions on financial solidarity and on how to fund the crisis and recovery package have not been fluid. Differing approaches, on notably the Recovery Fund, led the EU ministers to ask the European Council for guidance. However, considering these differences in views, EU leaders decided to move the issue to the Commission's table and tasked it with analysing the exact needs and producing a proposal as rapidly as possible. The Commission published its proposal on 27 May 2020, and the European Council agreed on the package at its meeting of 17-21 July 2020. A compromise deal on the long-term budget package including the MFF and Recovery Fund was finally reached by the EU institutions' negotiators in December 2020, after a stand-off with Hungary and Poland, with the (passive) support of Slovenia, blocking the deal in Council because of their objection to the rule of law conditionality stemming from their current national circumstances. https://www.consilium.europa.eu/media/43300/200410_peg-centeno-letter-to-pec-michel_covid.pdfhttps://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-eu-dombrovskis/eu-could-finance-1-5-trillion-euro-recovery-fund-with-bonds-dombrovskis-idUSKCN21W0KGhttps://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2020/04/09/report-on-the-comprehensive-economic-policy-response-to-the-covid-19-pandemic/https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2020/04/23/conclusions-by-president-charles-michel-following-the-video-conference-with-members-of-the-european-council-on-23-april-2020/https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/ip_20_940https://www.consilium.europa.eu/media/45109/210720-euco-final-conclusions-en.pdf https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/ip_20_2397 https://www.politico.eu/article/eu-should-hold-firm-against-hungary-poland-in-budget-fight-romanian-pm/

Current challenges in the area of migration relate not only to internal disagreements in the EU, but also to the recent actions of a number of third countries, which believe that irregular migration can be used as a means to exert pressure on the EU. Countries, including Turkey and Morocco, have threatened to or actually did allow migrants in large numbers to cross EU borders illegally, thereby 'weaponising migration'. Most recently, in the summer of 2021, Belarus started to fly in refugees and to direct them to Lithuania in reaction to EU sanctions, opening another migration route to the EU. At its meeting of 24-45 June 2021, the European Council condemned and rejected any attempt by third countries to 'instrumentalise migrants for political purposes'. European Council President, Charles Michel reiterated this message on 5 July and pledged solidarity with Lithuania. The situation remained charged in August, with over 4 000 migrants having crossed from Belarus into Lithuania this year (compared with 74 in 2020 and just 37 in 2019) and others arriving at the Latvian and Polish borders. Consequently, the Slovenian Presidency of the Council of the EU organised an extraordinary videoconference meeting of interior ministers within the framework of the Council's crisis response mechanism (IPCR), a tool used by EU countries to coordinate during acute crises. Ministers expressed their solidarity with Latvia, Lithuania and Poland and voiced support for providing additional assistance at these external EU borders. In this context, on 7 October 2021, interior ministers from 12 Member States sent a letter to Margaritis Schinas, Vice-President of the European Commission, and Ylva Johansson, Commissioner for Home Affairs, asking 'to adapt the existing legal framework to the new realities'. They noted, in particular, that 'a physical barrier appears to be an effective border protection measure', and proposed that measures in this regard should be 'additionally and adequately funded from the EU budget as a matter of priority'. Following the 21-22 October European Council, President von der Leyen outlined the EU's current and future support for Member States' border management, but also stated that 'there will be no [EU] funding of barbed wire and walls'. https://www.politico.eu/article/turkey-says-it-will-no-longer-stop-refugees-from-entering-europe/https://ecfr.eu/article/this-time-is-different-spain-morocco-and-weaponised-migration/https://euobserver.com/world/152305https://www.europarl.europa.eu/RegData/etudes/BRIE/2021/694201/EPRS_BRI(2021)694201_EN.pdfhttps://twitter.com/eucopresident/status/1412102714427953159https://euobserver.com/migration/152583https://euobserver.com/tickers/152632https://euobserver.com/tickers/152619https://twitter.com/EU2021SI/status/1425462408731049995https://slovenian-presidency.consilium.europa.eu/en/news/home-affairs-ministers-express-solidarity-with-the-eu-member-states-at-the-border-with-belarus/https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/documents-publications/publications/ipcr/?utm_source=POLITICO.EU&utm_campaign=0ca76056ca-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2021_08_12_05_07&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_10959edeb5-0ca76056ca-189688461https://slovenian-presidency.consilium.europa.eu/media/y5uoszrv/ipcr-presidency-statement-final_18-8-2021.pdfhttps://www.politico.eu/wp-content/uploads/2021/10/07/Joint-letter_Adaptation-of-EU-legal-framework-20211007.pdf https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/media-galleries/european-council/meetings/2021-10-21-22-euco/?slide=0

The current global taxation system is one hundred years old and thus is not fit for purpose in an increasingly digitalised and globalised economy. The OECD has been pursuing work under two pillars: (i) the re-allocation of some taxing rights over Multi National Enterprises to the markets where they have business activities and earn profits (ii) set a global minimum corporate tax rate that countries can use to protect their tax bases. Under pillar one, potential solutions are being examined by the Council to determine where tax should be paid and what portion of profits should be taxed. A broad outline of a unified approach on pillar one has been agreed as the basis for further negotiations at the end of January 2020, followed by the endorsement by the G20 finance ministers on 23 February 2020. However, the Commission will examine whether a directive is needed to ensure the consistent and effective implementation of pillar one at EU level. In July, the G20 Finance Ministers mandated the OECD to develop a blueprint on the design of the two pillars ahead of their next meeting on 15-16 October 2020; they were published on 12 October 2020. Under pillar two, a system will be designed to ensure that multinational enterprises pay a minimum level of tax. On 25 March 2021, the European Council stated the urgent need to address tax challenges resulting from digitalisation and highlighted their preference for a global solution by mid-2021 within the framework of the OECD. In June 2021, the G7 agreed on a global minimum corporate income tax rate of 15 %. The new rules would adjust taxing rights to countries where large multinational enterprises earn their profits. In October 2021, 136 countries agreed to support the tax reform, while four 13 countries have not yet backed the new two-pillar tax package. Three EU Member States (Ireland, Estonia and Hungary) recently joined the agreement; thus all Member States are now officially supporting the tax reform. In the EU, the agreement will need an EU law to be passed and that will require the unanimous agreement of all 27 Member States. https://www.oecd.org/newsroom/130-countries-and-jurisdictions-join-bold-new-framework-for-international-tax-reform.htmhttps://www.oecd.org/tax/beps/oecd-presents-analysis-showing-significant-impact-of-proposed-international-tax-reforms.htmhttps://data.consilium.europa.eu/doc/document/ST-13405-2019-INIT/en/pdfhttps://www.oecd.org/tax/beps/statement-by-the-oecd-g20-inclusive-framework-on-beps-january-2020.pdfhttps://agenceurope.eu/en/bulletin/article/12432/12https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/STATEMENT_21_5247https://www.oecd.org/tax/beps/oecd-g20-inclusive-framework-on-beps-invites-public-input-on-the-reports-on-pillar-one-and-pillar-two-blueprints.htmhttps://www.consilium.europa.eu/media/48976/250321-vtc-euco-statement-en.pdf https://www.politico.eu/article/oecd-global-tax-deal-reached-g20/

With the debates at the European Council meetings of 10-11 December 2020, 24-25 June 2021 and 21-22 October 2021, the issue of EU values has finally arrived at the level of EU Heads of State or Government. Recent developments, including court rulings at both EU and Member State levels alluding to the rule of law, indicate that deep divisions persist in the EU regarding the understanding of democracy and European values; observers argue that the EU's rule of law crisis is still far from being resolved. EU leaders' various discussions have not led to a solution on the issue, but rather postponed direct action at European level for the moment. Consequently, EU leaders might need to return to this topic again in the near future. https://data.consilium.europa.eu/doc/document/ST-22-2020-INIT/en/pdfhttps://www.europarl.europa.eu/RegData/etudes/BRIE/2021/694201/EPRS_BRI(2021)694201_EN.pdfhttps://www.europarl.europa.eu/RegData/etudes/BRIE/2021/694243/EPRS_BRI(2021)694243_EN.pdfhttps://curia.europa.eu/jcms/upload/docs/application/pdf/2021-10/cp210192en.pdf https://curia.europa.eu/juris/document/document.jsf?text=&docid=244185&pageIndex=0&doclang=FR&mode=req&dir=&occ=first&part=1&cid=1699703 https://www.politico.eu/article/poland-legal-eu-court-reprimand-disciplinary-procedure-for-judges/ https://www.politico.eu/article/five-ways-the-eus-democracy-crisis-could-end/ https://eu.boell.org/en/2020/12/18/after-crisis-crisis-rule-law-headache-wont-go-away

During the coronavirus crisis, the 'solidarity clause' in Article 122 TFEU has been used as legal basis for some of the actions taken to tackle the crisis and support the EU economy in the recovery process. Paragraph 2 states that 'where a Member State is in difficulties or is seriously threatened with severe difficulties caused by natural disasters or exceptional occurrences beyond its control, the Council, on a proposal from the Commission, may grant, under certain conditions, Union financial assistance to the Member State concerned'. The European Council is not specifically mentioned in this article. https://www.politico.eu/article/coronavirus-angela-merkel-eu-bonds/https://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:12008E122:EN:HTML

The European Council has been active during the crisis, and, like many actors, has taken a digital leap with its video-meetings. This new form of meetings has enabled EU leaders in a context of lockdown to take joint action to tackle the crisis. Considering the particular nature of the European Council however, and notably the importance of small bilateral meetings on the side-lines in achieving agreements, video meetings are unlikely to replace physical meetings fully when crucial decisions are on the agenda. In such a format, EU leaders tend to be more cautious and keep to their written statements since the confidentiality of discussions is not ensured and participation is broader than in formal physical meetings. After months of remote meetings, the European Council was able to convene again in person on 17-21 July 2020 when EU leaders discussed and reached a political agreement on the MFF and the recovery package. In the first half of 2021, EU Heads of State or Government were back online as the third wave of coronavirus hit Europe, but were able to meet in person again in June and October 2021. https://www.politico.eu/article/coronavirus-european-leaders-to-hold-videoconference/https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2020/04/23/conclusions-by-president-charles-michel-following-the-video-conference-with-members-of-the-european-council-on-23-april-2020/https://www.euractiv.com/section/global-europe/news/can-the-eu-be-run-by-videolink-confidentiality-is-the-biggest-problem/https://www.consilium.europa.eu/media/45109/210720-euco-final-conclusions-en.pdf

title: Online advertising: the impact of targeted advertising on advertisers, market access and consumer choice
snippet: In this research paper, we provide a comprehensive overview of online advertising markets and we analyse the challenges and opportunities concerning digital advertising. We review the degree to which existing and proposed legislation at EU level addresses the identified problems, and identify potential solutions, with reference to experience from EU Member States and third countries. We conclude with a synthesis and specific policy recommendations, drawing on stakeholder interviews. This document was provided by the Policy Department for Economic, Scientific and Quality of Life Policies for the committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection (IMCO).

title: IPR and the use of open data and data sharing initiatives by public and private actors
snippet: This study analyses recent developments in data related practice, law and policy as well as the current legal framework for data access, sharing, and use in the European Union. The study identifies particular issues of concern and highlights respective need for action. On this basis, the study evaluates the Commission’s proposal for a Data Act. The study is commissioned by the European Parliament’s Policy Department for Citizens’ Rights and Constitutional Affairs at the request of the Committee on Legal Affairs.

title: Key enabling technologies for Europe's technological sovereignty
snippet: Technological sovereignty has been at the heart of recent political debate in the EU. Interest has only been strengthened by the Covid-19 pandemic crisis, due to its impact on many value chains. Key enabling technologies (KETs) – advanced manufacturing and materials, life-science technologies, micro/nano-electronics and photonics, artificial intelligence, and security and connectivity technologies – are crucial for an interconnected, digitalised, resilient and healthier European society, as well as being important for the EU's competitiveness and position in the global economy. This STOA study analyses how the EU is performing in developing and protecting ownership and know-how in these critical technologies, especially in comparison with strong global players such as China and the USA. Based on the challenges identified in the analysis, it discusses policy options for strengthening the EU's technological sovereignty in KETs.

title: Future Shocks 2022: Addressing risks and building capabilities for Europe in a contested world
snippet: The coronavirus crisis has demonstrated not only that the European Union faces a variety of risks, and that those disparate risks are inter-linked, but that the response to such challenges to the Union - even in areas in which the EU does not have explicit competence - is stronger with the Union and its Member States acting together. Russia's war on Ukraine, which was launched while this study was being drafted, shows us not just the added value of concerted action by the Union but also the ability of EU institutions and Member States to find new and effective solutions to deal with major shocks. This paper, the first in an annual series, seeks to assess the risks to, and capabilities and resilience of, the EU system. Building on a review of global risks, it considers in detail specific risks with the potential to harm Europe and its people. It then sets out options for policy responses which can ensure Europe is more able to address the dangers of such risks and minimise the potential damage. Among the op...

news.reference_string: The European Peace Facility (EPF), an off-EU budget instrument that brings together the former Athena mechanism (common costs for CSDP military operations) and the African Peace Facility (mechanism to support peace and security in Africa), has been operational since 1 July 2021. The EPF consists of two pillars, namely 'military operations' and 'assistance measures'. It benefits from an envelope of nearly €6 billion for the period 2021-2027, funded by the EU Member States (except Denmark) 2 on a gross national income (GNI) basis. Prior to the start of the war, the Council pledged to provide €31 million in assistance to support the Ukrainian armed forces under the EPF, and similar decisions targeted Bosnia and Herzegovina (€10 million), Georgia (€11.4 million) and Moldova (€6.3 million). After the start of the war, the amount for Ukraine was increased by €500 million, of which €450 million for lethal arms and €50 million for non-lethal supplies, and political agreements were reached for two further increases of €500 million (thus totalling €1.5 billion). As EPF implementation begins, the question of the accountability of the money spent could progressively arise; this issue could be addressed by bringing the EPF into the EU budget and hence under the scrutiny of the European Parliament. https://www.europarl.europa.eu/thinktank/en/document/EPRS_ATA(2022)698906 https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/policies/athena/ https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/es/ip_19_3432 https://ec.europa.eu/fpi/what-we-do/european-peace-facility_en https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/PDF/?uri=CELEX:32021D2135&from=EN https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?uri=CELEX%3A32021D1923&qid=1644941865989 https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?uri=CELEX%3A32021D2134&qid=1644941865989 https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?uri=CELEX%3A32021D2136&qid=1644941865989 https://www.politico.eu/article/eu-ukraine-russia-funding-weapons-budget-military-aid/ https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/meetings/fac/2022/03/21/ https://www.ceps.eu/the-european-peace-facility/

Under the Biden administration, the USA and the EU have together launched or revived vehicles for democracy-to-democracy cooperation on the pandemic, the climate, trade, security and democracy. A new EU-US Trade and Technology Council (TTC) met at ministerial-level for the first time in in September 2021 in Pittsburgh (USA), and is expected to meet again in France in May 2022. The TTC aims to achieve transatlantic consensus fit for the democratic world on common standards, resilient supply chains, tech regulation, global trade challenges, climate and green tech, as well as investment screening and export controls. A new EU-US dialogue on security and defence is set to launch in 'early 2022', while a EU-US high-level dialogue on Russia was announced in June 2021 (although has yet to meet formally, possibly superseded by events). Two high-level meetings of the EU-US dialogue on China were launched in the final months of the Trump Administration. In contrast to email and telephone systems, which allow all users to interact regardless of which specific provider they use, social media platforms tend to restrict direct interaction with other services. This fosters dependency upon a single point of failure and is exacerbated by dominant market positions and high barriers for users to leave or change platform. In addition, some dominant platforms have expanded by providing login services for third parties. These vulnerabilities were well-illustrated by the October 2021 interruption to all Facebook services, including WhatsApp, Instagram and their login facilities for third party services. While the technical infrastructure remained fully functional, the failure of a single operator affected many dependent users in the same way as a global internet blackout would. https://www.europarl.europa.eu/thinktank/en/document/EPRS_ATA(2018)614559 https://www.wired.com/story/nigeria-whatsapp-facebook-outage/

Russia was in 2019 the EU's main external supplier of both natural gas (38 %) and crude oil (27 %), and some EU Member States remained highly dependent on Russian energy in their imports (see Figure 6). Russia's economy is heavily dependent on energy exports, most of which are directed towards EU countries. Following Russia's invasion of Ukraine, the EU decided to cut out its dependency on Russian fossil fuels, and the Commission is to present by mid- May 2022 a phasing-out plan by 2027. By supporting the twin transition, which would include more home-grown renewables and a higher of nuclear power, the EU could further reduce its energy dependency on fossil fuels. However, it will have to assess the impact of nuclear power on raw material imports, such as uranium, for which Russia is currently the EU's second biggest supplier, being outranked recently by Niger (the difference in quantities supplied is negligible, less than 1 %). https://www.politico.eu/article/moldova-wins-gazpr-contract-after-shortage-prompts-emergency-measures/ https://www.europarl.europa.eu/thinktank/en/document/EPRS_STU(2020)652096 https://www.europarl.europa.eu/thinktank/en/document/EPRS_BRI(2022)699488 https://twitter.com/vonderleyen/status/1502288794929831939 https://ec.europa.eu/environment/ecoap/about-eco-innovation/policies-matters/green-and-digital-twin-transition-also-spurs-inclusive-eco_en https://euratom-supply.ec.europa.eu/index_en

The EU and other democratic players also face direct threats from non-democracies, chief among them Russia and China, which increasingly act in concert. Russia has begun a war to challenge the existing security order in Europe and democracy in its neighbourhood, and also in Africa, while China uses trade restrictions to bully democracies in Europe and elsewhere that criticise it or offer support for democratic Taiwan. Both Russia and China are leading sources of disinformation aimed at democratic societies in the EU and elsewhere. In developing economies, China challenges EU interests first by using its Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) to draw developing countries into debt traps in order to acquire rights to infrastructure and resources beyond its borders, and second by providing an alternative, authoritarian model of development. In a world in which hard power still matters and national self-interest prevails, the EU – which is centred around soft power and is bound to balance the pursuit of its own interests with respect for international values – has constantly aimed to better leverage its economic and diplomatic influence, coordinate more effectively among its members, and build strategic partnerships with other major democracies and international regional organisations such as the African Union and ASEAN, which commit to democratic principles in their founding treaties. https://www.politico.eu/article/russia-china-oppose-nato-enlargement-vladimir-putin-xi-jinping-ukraine/https://thediplomat.com/2022/02/how-chinas-economic-coercion-is-bringing-lithuania-and-australia-together/https://www.europarl.europa.eu/RegData/etudes/BRIE/2022/698917/EPRS_BRI(2022)698917_EN.pdfhttps://www.europarl.europa.eu/RegData/etudes/STUD/2021/653633/EXPO_STU(2021)653633_EN.pdfhttps://www.europarl.europa.eu/RegData/etudes/BRIE/2021/698824/EPRS_BRI(2021)698824_EN.pdfhttps://carnegieendowment.org/2020/01/08/how-china-is-reshaping-international-development-pub-80703https://www.egmontinstitute.be/content/uploads/2015/12/Strategic-Partnership-Workshop-Report-final.pdf?type=pdf https://ec.europa.eu/international-partnerships/africa-eu-partnership_en https://www.eeas.europa.eu/eeas/eu-asean-strategic-partnership_en
