Media freedom on the decline: While the media are considered a fundamental pillar of democracy and the rule of law, both public and private media are often used and abused for political campaigns and propaganda. Furthermore, their digital transformation has had a profound impact on democratic politics. The disappearance of numerous newspapers, many of them local, has undermined civic engagement and political participation. The spread of social media and online news sources has made information more accessible, but has also contributed to the dissemination of fake news and disinformation. Meanwhile, there is a risk that measures to counter disinformation unnecessarily restrict freedom of expression. Increasing attacks and intimidation against journalists, traditionally considered to occur in authoritarian regimes, are also affecting developed democracies, often provoked and encouraged by populist or corrupt politicians. https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/theworldpost/wp/2018/03/21/newspapers/https://www.nytimes.com/2019/11/20/us/local-news-disappear-pen-america.htmlhttps://www.theguardian.com/media/2020/jul/28/local-journalism-democracy-us-newspapershttp://www.europarl.europa.eu/RegData/etudes/STUD/2021/695445/IPOL_STU(2021)695445_EN.pdf https://rsf.org/en/journalism-weakened-democracys-erosion

The EU has also shown itself willing to advance trade integration with democratic and nondemocratic partners alike. In December 2020, a 'political agreement' was announced on a comprehensive agreement on investment (CAI) with China, shortly before the Biden Administration took office. Some observers argued that the CAI undercut transatlantic cooperation on the challenges China poses to the multilateral trading system. In addition, while the EU has successfully concluded FTAs with Japan and Canada (even if the latter awaits ratification by all Member States), progress on FTAs with other democratic partners is slower than might have been expected: negotiations with Australia were delayed by the diplomatic dispute between that country and France over the AUKUS announcement, while France reportedly sought to postpone the conclusion of negotiations with New Zealand and Chile until after its presidential election. title: The performance of the Package Travel Directive and broader consumer protection issues in the implementation of passenger rights
snippet: This study evaluates the implementation and enforcement of the Package Travel Directive (PTD) in the EU with a focus on ten EU Member States. It identifies areas for improvement, such as adapting the definition of package travel to accommodate evolving industry trends, addressing pre-contractual information gaps, improving payment practices, tackling challenges in the digital environment, enhancing enforcement mechanisms, promoting alternative dispute resolution, and increasing consumer awareness. The study aims to enhance the PTD’s effectiveness, protect travellers’ rights, and foster a consumer-friendly package travel market in the EU. This document was provided by the Policy Department for Economic, Scientific and Quality of Life Policies for the committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection (IMCO).

title: Key Issues in the European Council - State of play in March 2023
snippet: This EPRS publication, ‘Key Issues in the European Council’, which will be updated quarterly to coincide with European Council meetings, aims to provide an overview of the institution’s activities on major EU issues. It analyses nine policy areas, explaining the legal and political background and the main priorities and orientations defined by the European Council. It also assesses the results of European Council involvement to date and identifies future challenges in the various policy fields.

news.reference_string: With the debates at the European Council meetings of 10-11 December 2020, 24-25 June 2021 and 21-22 October 2021, the issue of EU values has finally arrived at the level of EU Heads of State or Government. Recent developments, including court rulings at both EU and Member State levels alluding to the rule of law, indicate that deep divisions persist in the EU regarding the understanding of democracy and European values; observers argue that the EU's rule of law crisis is still far from being resolved. EU leaders' various discussions have not led to a solution on the issue, but rather postponed direct action at European level for the moment. Consequently, EU leaders might need to return to this topic again in the near future. At their meeting of 24-25 March 2022, the President of the European Parliament, Roberta Metsola, urged EU leaders to use the current 'window of opportunity' to find a way forward on the rule of law. https://data.consilium.europa.eu/doc/document/ST-22-2020-INIT/en/pdfhttps://www.europarl.europa.eu/RegData/etudes/BRIE/2021/694201/EPRS_BRI(2021)694201_EN.pdfhttps://www.europarl.europa.eu/RegData/etudes/BRIE/2021/694243/EPRS_BRI(2021)694243_EN.pdfhttps://curia.europa.eu/jcms/upload/docs/application/pdf/2021-10/cp210192en.pdf https://curia.europa.eu/juris/document/document.jsf?text=&docid=244185&pageIndex=0&doclang=FR&mode=req&dir=&occ=first&part=1&cid=1699703 https://www.politico.eu/article/poland-legal-eu-court-reprimand-disciplinary-procedure-for-judges/ https://www.politico.eu/article/five-ways-the-eus-democracy-crisis-could-end/ https://eu.boell.org/en/2020/12/18/after-crisis-crisis-rule-law-headache-wont-go-away https://www.europarl.europa.eu/news/en/press-room/20220324IPR26159/this-is-our-moment-president-metsola-to-eu-leaders

In October 2022, in the context of the energy- and economy-related challenges facing the EU, the European Council called for all relevant EU and national level tools to be utilised to boost the resilience of the EU economy. However, they also noted the importance of preserving the level playing and the 'integrity of the single market' whilst maintaining Europe's global competitiveness. The growing use of subsidies worldwide, more particularly the adoption of the US IRA, has caused concern for some in the EU, who see it as discriminatory and a violation of WTO rules, and as having a potentially damaging effect on the EU green tech industry. Despite differing views on how or whether to change State aid policy, the European Council agreed that it was imperative for the EU to be competitive and productive, particularly in sectors connected to the digital and green transitions. The European Council has agreed that State aid policy needs adjusting in order to become simpler, faster and more predictable, allowing for temporary and proportionate support. Finding the correct balance between enabling State aid to support EU industry and preserving the level playing field in the single market will be a key challenge for the EU and its Member States over the coming months. To monitor these developments, the European Council has asked the Commission to report regularly on the impact of State aid policy on the single market as well as on the EU's competitiveness globally. https://www.europarl.europa.eu/thinktank/en/document/EPRS_BRI(2022)743681 https://www.oecd.org/subsidies/ https://www.whitehouse.gov/cleanenergy/inflation-reduction-act-guidebook/ https://borderlex.net/2023/02/21/think-tank-responding-to-the-united-states-green-tech-subsidies/ https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2023-01-18/why-eu-objects-to-us-green-subsidies-tax-breaks-quicktake?cmpid=BBD012723_BRUS&utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&utm_term=230127&utm_campaign=brussels&leadSource=uverify%20wall https://epthinktank.eu/2023/02/07/outlook-for-the-special-european-council-meeting-of-9-10-february-2023/#:%7E:text=and%20Annastiina%20Papunen.-,EU%20Heads%20of%20State%20or%20Government%20will%20gather%20on%209,migration%20and%20the%20EU%27s%20economy.

Following the Charlie Hebdo attacks, for example, after which millions of people had expressed their solidarity with the victims (through the 'Je suis Charlie' movement), an informal European Council meeting was held on 12 February 2015. At that meeting, Heads of State or Government adopted a statement on anti-terrorism measures, vowing to take stronger measures against terrorist threats in the coming months. Taxation has been a very visible topic in the EU in recent years. According to some estimates, tax evasion, tax avoidance and aggressive tax planning could cause a loss of as much as €1 trillion in tax income to the EU annually. In its June 2018 conclusions, the European Council said that the 'fight against tax avoidance, evasion and fraud must be vigorously pursued both at global level (notably in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD)) and within the EU'. Commission President Ursula von der Leyen, in her political guidelines, outlined: 'I will ensure that taxation of big tech companies is a priority. I will work hard to ensure the proposals currently on the table are turned into law.' https://www.reuters.com/article/us-eu-tax-vanrompuy-idUSBRE93B0KC20130412https://data.consilium.europa.eu/doc/document/ST-9-2018-INIT/en/pdfhttps://ec.europa.eu/info/sites/default/files/political-guidelines-next-commission_en_0.pdf

title: Key issues in the European Council: State of play in December 2022
snippet: The role of the European Council is to 'provide the Union with the necessary impetus for its development' and to define its 'general political directions and priorities'. Since its creation in 1975, the European Council has exercised considerable influence over the development of the European Union, a process enhanced by its designation as a formal institution of the Union under the Lisbon Treaty in 2009. The European Council Oversight Unit within the European Parliamentary Research Service (EPRS) monitors and analyses the activities, commitments and impact of the European Council, so as to maximise parliamentary understanding of the political dynamics of this important institution. This EPRS publication, 'Key issues in the European Council', which is updated every quarter to coincide with European Council meetings, aims to provide an overview of the institution's activities on major EU issues. It analyses twelve broad policy areas, explaining the legal and political background, the main priorities and ori...

news.reference_string: Taxation has been a very visible topic in the EU in recent years. The European Parliament has set up several special committees on this topic over the years, TAXE, TAX2, TAX3, the PANA committee of inquiry, and in the current legislature, a new subcommittee on tax matters (FISC). They have all looked into tax evasion, tax avoidance and aggressive tax planning, which according to some estimates could cause a loss to the EU of as much as €1 trillion in tax income annually. https://www.europarl.europa.eu/doceo/document/TA-8-2015-0408_EN.htmlhttps://www.europarl.europa.eu/doceo/document/TA-8-2016-0310_EN.htmlhttps://www.europarl.europa.eu/doceo/document/TA-8-2019-0240_EN.html https://www.europarl.europa.eu/thinktank/en/document/EPRS_ATA(2017)614619 https://www.europarl.europa.eu/committees/en/fisc/home/highlights https://www.reuters.com/article/us-eu-tax-vanrompuy-idUSBRE93B0KC20130412

In the digital age, earning profit in a country no longer necessarily requires setting-up factories or offices on the ground, but can be effected by offering products or services through digital platforms. This results in the difficulty of localising value creation, and as a result, the ensuing taxation questions become increasingly complicated. The issue has caused some transatlantic tensions, as the United States (US) has a very strong 'big tech' digital presence around the world. The US has raised the possibility to impose unilateral tariffs if EU countries were to go ahead with a digital levy. At its March 2021 meeting, the European Council has expressed its preference for and commitment to a global solution within the OECD framework. However, it did not rule out a unilateral EU move if a global solution were not achieved. https://www.politico.eu/article/eu-to-postpone-digital-tax-proposal/https://www.consilium.europa.eu/media/48976/250321-vtc-euco-statement-en.pdf

Security of 5G networks. The European Council stated in March 2019 that it looks forward 'to the Commission's recommendation on a concerted approach to the security of 5G networks'. The recommendation was published a few days after the European Council meeting. Since then, the security of 5G networks, and especially the involvement of the Chinese technology giant Huawei in building the networks, has been a widely discussed topic, notably following the move by the US to block Huawei from its market and to encourage its allies to adopt a similar approach. On 29 January 2020, the Commission published the EU toolbox on 5G cybersecurity, in which it outlined a set of key actions to ensure the security of the networks, such as limiting dependency on a single supplier and assessing the risk profile of supplies. The multivendor approach has been interpreted by Huawei as meaning that it will be able to take part in building the European 5G networks. The Commission has called on the Member States to 'take concrete and measurable steps' to implement key toolbox measures. EU leaders discussed 5G at their meeting on 1-2 October 2020 and stressed that 'potential 5G suppliers need to be assessed on the basis of common objective criteria' and asked the Member States to send their national plans on the roll-out of 5G to the Commission to 'ensure the rapid deployment of 5G across the EU'. https://data.consilium.europa.eu/doc/document/ST-1-2019-INIT/en/pdf https://ec.europa.eu/newsroom/dae/document.cfm?doc_id=58154 https://www.bloomberg.com/opinion/articles/2019-11-23/huawei-s-5g-networks-are-a-paralyzing-dilemma-for-the-west https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/ip_20_123 https://agenceurope.eu/en/bulletin/article/12414/7 https://huawei.eu/press-release/huawei-media-statement-following-publication-european-commissions-5g-security-toolbox https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/qanda_20_127 https://www.consilium.europa.eu/media/45910/021020-euco-final-conclusions.pdf?utm_source=dsms-auto&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=European+Council+conclusions%2c+1-2+October+2020

It has been reported that the file has been blocked as a means to pressure the European Commission into approving the Polish recovery plans. https://newsroom.consilium.europa.eu/events/20220405-economic-and-financial-affairs-council-april-2022/134695-1-press-conference-part-1-20220405 https://www.politico.eu/newsletter/brussels-playbook/black-death-rule-of-law-polands-blockade/ https://www.euractiv.com/section/economy-jobs/news/poland-blocks-eu-directive-to-implement-global-corporate-tax-deal/

The coronavirus crisis has had an unprecedented impact on the euro area, with economic output shrinking by 6 % in 2020.The shock to EU economies has been symmetrical, and recovery has been stopped short. The discussions on financial solidarity and on how to fund the crisis and recovery package have not been fluid. Differing approaches, on notably the Recovery Fund, led the EU ministers to ask the European Council for guidance. However, considering these differences in views, EU leaders decided to move the issue to the Commission's table and tasked it with analysing the exact needs and producing a proposal as rapidly as possible. The Commission published its proposal on 27 May 2020, and the European Council agreed on the package at its meeting of 17-21 July 2020. A compromise deal on the long-term budget package including the MFF and Recovery Fund was finally reached by the EU institutions' negotiators in December 2020, after a stand-off with Hungary and Poland, with the (passive) support of Slovenia, blocking the deal in the Council because of their objection to the rule of law conditionality stemming from their current national circumstances. https://ec.europa.eu/info/sites/default/files/economy-finance/ip156_en.pdfhttps://www.consilium.europa.eu/media/43300/200410_peg-centeno-letter-to-pec-michel_covid.pdfhttps://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-eu-dombrovskis/eu-could-finance-1-5-trillion-euro-recovery-fund-with-bonds-dombrovskis-idUSKCN21W0KGhttps://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2020/04/09/report-on-the-comprehensive-economic-policy-response-to-the-covid-19-pandemic/https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2020/04/23/conclusions-by-president-charles-michel-following-the-video-conference-with-members-of-the-european-council-on-23-april-2020/https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/ip_20_940https://www.consilium.europa.eu/media/45109/210720-euco-final-conclusions-en.pdf https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/ip_20_2397 https://www.politico.eu/article/eu-should-hold-firm-against-hungary-poland-in-budget-fight-romanian-pm/

title: Key issues in the European Council: State of play in May 2022
snippet: The role of the European Council is to 'provide the Union with the necessary impetus for its development' and to define its 'general political directions and priorities'. Since its creation in 1975, the European Council has exercised considerable influence over the development of the European Union, a process enhanced by its designation as a formal institution of the Union under the Lisbon Treaty in 2009. The European Council Oversight Unit within the European Parliamentary Research Service (EPRS) monitors and analyses the activities, commitments and impact of the European Council, so as to maximise parliamentary understanding of the political dynamics of this important institution. This EPRS publication, 'Key issues in the European Council', which is updated every quarter to coincide with European Council meetings, aims to provide an overview of the institution's activities on major EU issues. It analyses twelve broad policy areas, explaining the legal and political background, the main priorities and ori...

news.reference_string: In October 2020, EU leaders held a strategic debate to discuss preparations ahead of the next meeting with the African Union (AU) on 9 December 2020. This meeting was cancelled again, this time due to scheduling issues. In February 2022, the heads of state or government of the Member States of the EU and the AU met for the sixth EU-AU summit. Both sides agreed to boost regional and continental economic integration through trade. The issue of waiving intellectual property rights on vaccines caused tension between both parties in advance of the summit and it had been under discussion at the World Trade Organization since October 2020. However, in their joint statement the EU and the AU agreed to engage 'constructively towards an agreement on a comprehensive WTO response to the pandemic, which includes trade-related, as well as intellectual property related aspects'. Discussions appear to be making genuine progress and the European Council welcomed this at its meeting in March 2022. https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2020/10/16/european-council-conclusions-15-16-october-2020/ https://www.politico.eu/article/eu-au-videoconference-postponed-over-agenda-issues/ https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2022/02/18/sixth-european-union-african-union-summit-a-joint-vision-for-2030/#:%7E:text=14%3A20-,Sixth%20European%20Union%20%2D%20African%20Union%20Summit%3A%20A%20Joint%20Vision%20for,the%20European%20Council%20and%20H.E. https://ustr.gov/about-us/policy-offices/press-office/press-releases/2022/march/statement-ustr-spokesperson-adam-hodge-wto-trips-waiver-discussions https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/meetings/european-council/2022/03/24-25/

The European Council held a debate on the regional situation in the western Balkans in March 2017. The debate was of two-fold importance: 1) it reaffirmed the European perspective of the western Balkans and 2) placed enlargement back on the political agenda of the EU. At the end of 2019, however, the enlargement process was in stalemate with several Member States in the European Council opposing the opening of accession negotiations with North Macedonia and Albania, while France was calling for a revision of the enlargement rules. https://www.europarl.europa.eu/RegData/etudes/BRIE/2019/642801/EPRS_BRI(2019)642801_EN.pdf https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-50100201

Taxation has been a very visible topic in the EU in recent years. The European Parliament has set up several special committees with limited mandates over the years on the topic, TAXE, TAX2, TAX3, the PANA committee of inquiry, and in the current legislature, a new subcommittee on tax matters (FISC). They have all looked into tax evasion, tax avoidance and aggressive tax planning, which according to some estimates could cause a loss to the EU of as much as €1 trillion in tax income annually. https://www.europarl.europa.eu/doceo/document/TA-8-2015-0408_EN.htmlhttps://www.europarl.europa.eu/doceo/document/TA-8-2016-0310_EN.htmlhttps://www.europarl.europa.eu/doceo/document/TA-8-2019-0240_EN.html https://www.europarl.europa.eu/thinktank/en/document/EPRS_ATA(2017)614619 https://www.europarl.europa.eu/committees/en/fisc/home/highlights https://www.reuters.com/article/us-eu-tax-vanrompuy-idUSBRE93B0KC20130412

EU leaders' various discussions have not led to a solution on the issue, but rather postponed direct action at European level for the moment. Security of 5G networks. The European Council stated in March 2019 that it looks forward 'to the Commission's recommendation on a concerted approach to the security of 5G networks'. The recommendation was published a few days after the European Council meeting. Since then, the security of 5G networks, and especially the involvement of the Chinese technology giant Huawei in building the networks, has been a widely discussed topic, notably following the move by the US to block Huawei from its market and to encourage its allies to adopt a similar approach. On 29 January 2020, the Commission published the EU toolbox on 5G cybersecurity, in which it outlined a set of key actions to ensure the security of the networks, such as limiting dependency on a single supplier and assessing the risk profile of supplies. The multivendor approach has been interpreted by Huawei as meaning that it will be able to take part in building the European 5G networks. The Commission has called on the Member States to 'take concrete and measurable steps' to implement key toolbox measures. EU leaders discussed 5G at their meeting on 1-2 October 2020 and stressed that 'potential 5G suppliers need to be assessed on the basis of common objective criteria' and asked the Member States to send their national plans on the roll-out of 5G to the Commission to 'ensure the rapid deployment of 5G across the EU'. https://data.consilium.europa.eu/doc/document/ST-1-2019-INIT/en/pdf https://ec.europa.eu/newsroom/dae/document.cfm?doc_id=58154 https://www.bloomberg.com/opinion/articles/2019-11-23/huawei-s-5g-networks-are-a-paralyzing-dilemma-for-the-west https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/ip_20_123 https://agenceurope.eu/en/bulletin/article/12414/7 https://huawei.eu/press-release/huawei-media-statement-following-publication-european-commissions-5g-security-toolbox https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/qanda_20_127 https://www.consilium.europa.eu/media/45910/021020-euco-final-conclusions.pdf?utm_source=dsms-auto&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=European+Council+conclusions%2c+1-2+October+2020

The EU supports the abovementioned tax package, even though it has been working on its own digital tax to deal with the issue. In 2018, the European Commission put forward two proposals for fair and effective taxation of the digital economy: a short-term solution, to be delivered by an interim digital services tax on revenues from certain digital services, and a permanent reform of corporate tax rules, based on the concept of 'significant digital presence'. Progress at EU level was stalled in an effort to find a global solution with the OECD. At the July 2020 European Council meeting, EU leaders tasked the Commission with putting forward a proposal on a digital levy in the first semester of 2021, considering ongoing OECD negotiations. As agreed in the interinstitutional agreement of 16 December 2020, such a levy was due to be one of the EU budget's new 'own resources' that would contribute to paying off EU debts incurred to finance the recovery package as well as play an important role in the fair taxation of digital companies. In December 2021, the Commission proposed a directive on ensuring a global minimum level of taxation for multinational groups in the Union, which closely follows the international agreement with adjustments to ensure compliance with EU law. In April 2022 at the Economic and Financial Affairs Council meeting, Poland vetoed the latest compromise proposal by the French Presidency, thereby blocking the file. It has been reported that the file has been blocked as a means to pressure the European Commission into approving the Polish recovery plans. https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/QANDA_21_3564https://ec.europa.eu/taxation_customs/business/company-tax/fair-taxation-digital-economy_enhttps://www.consilium.europa.eu/media/45109/210720-euco-final-conclusions-en.pdf https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?uri=uriserv:OJ.LI.2020.433.01.0028.01.ENG https://ec.europa.eu/info/strategy/eu-budget/long-term-eu-budget/2021-2027/revenue/potential-new-sources-revenue_en https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?uri=CELEX%3A52021PC0823&qid=1641150862839 https://newsroom.consilium.europa.eu/events/20220405-economic-and-financial-affairs-council-april-2022/134695-1-press-conference-part-1-20220405 https://www.politico.eu/newsletter/brussels-playbook/black-death-rule-of-law-polands-blockade/ https://www.euractiv.com/section/economy-jobs/news/poland-blocks-eu-directive-to-implement-global-corporate-tax-deal/

Another challenging factor during the coronavirus crisis has been the German federal constitutional court's critical ruling on the European Central Bank's bond buying programme, which has met with mixed reactions. https://www.ft.com/content/a1beda5e-5c2d-429e-a095-27728ed2d72b https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/statement_20_846 https://www.ft.com/content/f48e3a6b-6a95-4187-8a7d-0f8dad3fbecb

A further issue to contend with is the renewed discussions on the revision of fiscal coordination and the European Semester. The Stability and Growth Pact (SGP) was developed as part of the introduction of the euro and was reinforced in the aftermath of the sovereign debt crisis. The framework aims to keep countries' deficit below 3 % of economic output and their public debt below 60 %. Current rules allow Member States some leeway to bend the rules and get away without any fines, which could, if applied (not applied until now) amount to 0.2 % of the country's GDP. Eurozone debt decreased slightly to 95.6 % of economic output (88.1 % of GDP in EU as a whole) in the fourth quarter of 2021, compared with 100 % at the end of the first quarter, with the highest levels reached in Greece, Italy, Portugal, Spain, France, Belgium and Cyprus. The Commission has relaunched the debate on the review of EU economic governance, which had begun before the pandemic; the crisis led the EU to suspend the rules in March 2020 by activating the so-called general escape clause. This move enabled governments to take a supportive fiscal stance and to support their economies in the face of the economic and social impact of the pandemic. The rules are set to be applied again only in 2023 on the basis of the Commission's spring 2021 economic forecast. https://pro.politico.eu/news/138913 https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/documents/2995521/14497745/2-22042022-BP-EN.pdf/90896015-2ac1-081a-2eef-ad8d5f2c0da1 https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/SPEECH_21_5374 https://ec.europa.eu/info/business-economy-euro/economic-and-fiscal-policy-coordination/economic-governance-review_en https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/ip_21_2722

In the digital age, earning profit in a country no longer necessarily requires setting-up factories or offices on the ground, but can be effected by offering products or services through digital platforms. This results in the difficulty of localising value creation, and as a result, the ensuing taxation questions become increasingly complicated. The issue has caused some transatlantic tensions, as the United States (US) has a very strong 'big tech' digital presence around the world. The US has raised the possibility to impose unilateral tariffs if EU countries were to go ahead with a digital levy. In its March 2021 meeting, the European Council has expressed its preference for and commitment to a global solution within the OECD framework. However, it did not rule out a unilateral EU move if a global solution was not achieved. The European Parliament adopted its position on the matter in https://www.politico.eu/article/eu-to-postpone-digital-tax-proposal/https://www.consilium.europa.eu/media/48976/250321-vtc-euco-statement-en.pdfhttps://www.europarl.europa.eu/doceo/document/TA-9-2021-0147_EN.html

The European Council has been active during the crisis, and, like many actors, has taken a digital leap with its video-meetings. This new form of meetings has enabled EU leaders in a context of lockdown to take joint action to tackle the crisis. Considering the particular nature of the European Council however, and notably the importance of small bilateral meetings on the side-lines in achieving agreements, video meetings are unlikely to replace physical meetings fully when crucial decisions are on the agenda. In such a format, EU leaders tend to be more cautious and keep to their written statements since the confidentiality of discussions is not ensured and participation is broader than in formal physical meetings. After months of remote meetings, the European Council was able to convene again in person on 17-21 July 2020 when EU leaders discussed and reached a political agreement on the MFF and the recovery package. In the first half of 2021, EU Heads of State or Government were back online as the third wave of coronavirus hit Europe, but were able to meet in person again in June and October 2021. https://www.politico.eu/article/coronavirus-european-leaders-to-hold-videoconference/https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2020/04/23/conclusions-by-president-charles-michel-following-the-video-conference-with-members-of-the-european-council-on-23-april-2020/https://www.euractiv.com/section/global-europe/news/can-the-eu-be-run-by-videolink-confidentiality-is-the-biggest-problem/https://www.consilium.europa.eu/media/45109/210720-euco-final-conclusions-en.pdf

In recent weeks and months, the EU-China relationship has further deteriorated. When Taiwan opened a representative office in Lithuania, China reportedly responded by imposing an import ban, an export ban and restriction of services to and from Lithuania or linked to Lithuania. This led to the EU launching a case against China at the WTO for 'discriminatory trade practices' that impact both Lithuania and the EU single market. https://www.politico.eu/article/eu-sues-china-wto-lithuania-blockade/ https://docs.wto.org/dol2fe/Pages/SS/directdoc.aspx?filename=q:/WT/DS/610-1.pdf&Open=True https://trade.ec.europa.eu/doclib/press/index.cfm?id=2355

title: Civil liability regime for artificial intelligence
snippet: The findings of this European added value assessment (EAVA) suggest that the revision of the EU civil liability regime for artificial intelligence systems (AI) would likely generate substantial economic and social added value. The current preliminary analysis suggests that by 2030, EU action on liability could generate €54.8 billion in added value for the EU economy by stepping up the level of research and development in AI and in the range of €498.3 billion if other broader impacts, including reductions in accidents, health and environmental impacts and user impacts are also taken into consideration. A clear and coherent EU civil liability regime for AI has the potential to reduce risks and increase safety, decrease legal uncertainty and related legal and litigation costs, and enhance consumer rights and trust. Those elements together could facilitate the faster and arguably safer uptake and diffusion of AI. Member States have not yet adopted specific legislation related to the regulation of liability...
